Cassie

Cassie v1.0 documentation

API Documentation¶

As a small library, Cassie exposes few things, all properly contained under the cassie namespace. If you’re running Cassie in an environment that doesn’t offer support for CommonJS modules, Cassie will create a new namespace inside the global (usually window) object. Otherwise, you just bind the exported data to whatever variable you want.

module Cassie¶

Obj forgotten: { }

A constant that indicates the Promise has failed through a call to forget().

Obj timeouted: { }

A constant that indicates the Promise failed for running out of its allowed time.

clean() → Obj¶

Restores the value of the global cassie property before Cassie was defined, and returns a reference to Cassie.

You can use this function as a workaround in the unlike event that the global cassie has already been taken. Or just to have a local reference to it instead of letting it pollute your globals:

<script type="text/javascript">
    window.cassie = "Cassandra"
</script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="cassie.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
    cassie // { clean: function() { ... }, ... }
    var future = cassie.clean()
    cassie // "Cassandra"
</script>

Warning

This method is only available on environments that doesn’t support CommonJS modules. It’s not provided in Node.js and such environments.

object Promise¶

class Promise¶

Creates a deferred object, which can be manipulated before the value it refers to is actually resolved. As soon as the Promise is fulfilled, all pending actions will be applied.

You can either return the promise directly, or take full advantage of it by inheriting the Promise prototype and adding your own custom methods.

See also

Unleashing the Power for more information on how the Promise works and how you can extend it.

Attributes¶

Although the attributes for Promise are exposed, you shouldn’t manipulate them directly. As such, these are considered internal and may have its behaviour changed without prior warning.

Obj callbacks: { }

A map of event → callbacks that the Promise knows about.

Array flush_queue: [ ]

A list of events that will have their list of callbacks flushed as soon as the Promise’s value is resolved.

Obj value: null

The value of the Promise. Any falsy value indicates that the Promise hasn’t been resolved yet.

The resolution function will always set the value as an array of arguments, which will in turn be passed to the callbacks waiting for the resolution of the Promise.

Num timer: null

A timer ID returned by timeout().

Str defaultev: 'done'

The queue on which callbacks are added by default, when an event queue is not explicitly passed to add().

Prototype methods¶

add([Str event][, Fn callback]) → Promise¶

Adds a callback to the Promise and changes the default event queue.

Parameters:
  • event (Str) – The event queue to which the callback should be added.
  • callback(args...) (Fn) – A function that should be called when this event happens. Such function will take as its parameters the value of the Promise.

Both parameters for the add() method are optional.

Should event not be given, the Promise will just use the default event queue (defaultev), and place the callback there. Having this default queue allows less repeating yourself all over the place:

// foo, bar and baz are added to queue 'ok'
promise.add('ok').add(foo).add(bar).add(baz)

On the other hand, if the callback is not given, the function will just change the default event queue to the given event.

And, obviously, if neither arguments are given, the function won’t do anything.

The add() is quite “low-level” though, and the specialised functions should be preferred when available (ok(), failed(), etc).

flush(Str event) → Promise¶

Calls all callbacks associated with the given event.

Parameters:event (Str) – the event queue to flush.

The flush method does two different things, depending on whether the Promise has been resolved or not. If the promise still hasn’t a value, this method will add the event to the flush_queue. Otherwise, it’ll fire all the callbacks for the events in the flush_queue, then clear the queue.

Callbacks are called in the context of the current Promise, with the promise’s value array applied as the callback arguments.

done(Arrayish values) → Promise¶

Resolves the Promise to the given values and flushes the callbacks defined for done.

Parameters:values (Arrayish) – Any array-like object to be passed as arguments to the callbacks.
Fires :done

The given values array-like object is cloned by simple applying Array.prototype.slice to it. This makes it easier for caller functions to just pass the arguments object straight up into this method.

If the Promise has already been resolved, this method does nothing, otherwise it’ll flush all callbacks in the flush_queue, plus the done event queue.

Done is the lowest level of Promise resolution, and shouldn’t really be called directly (unless you want to introduce a new class of primitive Promise state). Instead, take a look at bind() and fail().

See also

Specialised states for an explanation of the order in which these callback queues are flushed.

fail(Obj error) → Promise¶

Fails to fulfill the promise,

Parameters:error (Obj) – An object describing why the function error’d.
Fires :fail

This function is used to indicate that a function can’t be fulfilled, and as such any callback waiting for the function to error should be called.

Fail is a low-level, general error routine. For more specialised methods see timeout() and forget().

See also

done() for information on how the callbacks are flushed.

bind(values...) → Promise¶

Successfully fulfills the Promise.

Parameters:values – Positional parameters to be passed to all callbacks waiting for this Promise to be resolved.
Fires :ok
timeout(Num delay) → Promise¶

Fails to fulfill the Promise after the given number of seconds.

Parameters:delay (Num) – The number of seconds to wait before failing to fulfill this Promise.
Fires :timeouted

This method will fail to fulfill the Promise with the value of timeouted. Callbacks bound to fail can analyse the parameter to see why the Promise failed.

clear_timer() → Promise¶

Clears any timer that may have been set with timeout().

forget() → Promise¶

Immediately fails to fulfill the Promise.

Fires :forgotten

This method will fail to fulfill the Promise with the value of forgotten. Callbacks bound to fail can analyse the parameter to see why the Promise failed.
